The table above shows several Riemann sum approximations to <math> <mrow> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mn>1</mn> </msubsup> <mrow> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mi>x</mi> </mfrac> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle></mrow> </math>dx using right-hand endpoints of n subintervals of equal length of the interval [0,1] . Which of the following statements best describes the limit of the Riemann sums as n approaches infinity?

choices.label: The limit of the Riemann sums is a finite number less than 10.
The limit of the Riemann sums is a finite number greater than 10.

The limit of the Riemann sums does not exist because <math> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mrow> <msub> <mi>x</mi> <mi>n</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mi>n</mi> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </math> does not approach 0.
The limit of the Riemann sums does not exist because it is a sum of infinitely many positive numbers.

The limit of the Riemann sums does not exist because <math> <mrow> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mn>1</mn> </msubsup> <mrow> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mi>x</mi> </mfrac> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle></mrow> </math> dx does not exist.
